choices.C: Configure Device Connector Access Mode as Allow Control in Device Console. Claim the device on Intersight as Intersight Managed Mode.
choices.D: Configure Device Connector Access Mode as Allow Control in Cisco UCS Manager. Claim the device on Intersight as Intersight Managed Mode.
choices.B: Configure Device Connector Access Mode as Allow Control in Cisco UCS Manager. Claim the device on Intersight as UCSM Managed Mode.
choices.A: Configure Device Connector Access Mode as Allow Control in Device Consol. Claim the device on Intersight as UCSM Managed Mode.

questions.question_text: An engineer must configure a Cisco UCS domain for monitoring and management by the Cisco Intersight SaaS platform. After the setup is complete, administrators must have full control to configure the device through Cisco UCS Manager and Intersight. Which set of actions accomplishes this task?

discussion.content: Only with UCSM Managed Mode it is possibe to have full access to UCSM.

Selected Answer: B
It is B (9 year UCS admin here)

As others have mentioned, Intersight Managed Mode (IMM) completely removes UCSM from the system. They are looking to stay in UMM. 

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/unified_computing/ucs/ucs-manager/GUI-User-Guides/Admin-Management/3-2/b_Cisco_UCS_Admin_Mgmt_Guide_3_2/b_Cisco_UCS_Admin_Mgmt_Guide_3_2_chapter_010000.html#task_msq_4kh_5y

In the Navigation pane, click Admin.
Expand All > Device Connector.
<Snip>
Configures Access mode settings.
Access Mode—Configure access as Read-only or Allow Control.
Read-only—When the Read-only access mode is selected, you cannot configure the device through Intersight.
Allow Control—When the Allow Control access mode is selected, you have full control to configure the device through Intersight.

Selected Answer: B
I don't think B is fully correct, but it's the one closest to the requirements. When we claim a UCSM Managed Mode system on Intersight, we can do some operations, but not all of them. Intersight Managed Mode (IMM) wouldn't allow us to manage UCS using UCS Manager at all (since we wouldn't even have UCSM running on the FIs) - so D is incorrect.
Interesting video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zve2VK5W6_0

Selected Answer: D
If you are using Device Connector in UCSM, you have two options: read only and allow control. After that you claims device id stuff in Intersight and UCS becomes UCS Intersight Managed Mode. There are no such option in intersight as ucs managed mode. You just disconnects ucsm from Intersight. So i choose D, most logical answer

Selected Answer: B
it should be B, to have UCSM and IS
C and D are wrong, on intersight managed mode UCSM wont be available on the domain, the question states that can be controlled on intersight AND UCSM so the correct answer is B

Selected Answer: C
C is correct

On the below video, we can see that the Device Connector is configured on UCS Manager and that the Access Mode is being set to "Allow Control". Based on this, I believe the answer should be (D).

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I7gXnMQ8Iqw

C should be right

Device Connector
Device connector connects Cisco UCS Manager to Cisco Intersight, the cloud-hosted server management system. It enables Cisco UCS Manager to be managed and monitored through Cisco Intersight.

To register a device with Cisco Intersight in the cloud, you must do the following:

Connect Cisco UCS Manager with Cisco Intersight by configuring the device connector proxy settings, if they are required.

Use the device serial number and security code to validate your access to the device from Cisco Intersight and claim the device.

C is correct according to https://www.intersight.com/help/saas/getting_started/claim_targets#target_claim_for_compute/fabric_hyperconverged_orchestrator_and_platform_services_targets

Target: Cisco UCS Domain (Intersight Managed)
Device Connector Location: Device connector is device console

Selected Answer: D
it must D, to have full control in both manager ucs and intersight

Selected Answer: D
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/unified_computing/ucs/ucs-manager/GUI-User-Guides/Admin-Management/3-2/b_Cisco_UCS_Admin_Mgmt_Guide_3_2/b_Cisco_UCS_Admin_Mgmt_Guide_3_2_chapter_010000.html#:~:text=Updating%20Device%20Connector-,Device%20Connector,-Device%20connector%20connects

Selected Answer: B
it must B, to have ucsm and intersight manage

not append(), update() method is correct!

switch_id_list = {
 "N9K-SPINE-1" : "0000",
 "N9K-LEAF-1" : "1111",
 "N9K-LEAF-2" : "2222"
 }
switch_id_list.update({"N9K-Spine-2" : "3333"})
print(switch_id_list)
===============================================
{'N9K-SPINE-1': '0000', 'N9K-LEAF-1': '1111', 'N9K-LEAF-2': '2222', 'N9K-Spine-2': '3333'}

this switch_id_list type is "dict" not "list" ( plz using type() func! )
if it's type was "list" that append() method might be correct.

comments.content: It IS option D. That is a dictionary. And has a key-value pair. denoted by curly braces and the "key":"value" pair.
Option D is incorrect because the "update" method is used to update an existing key-value pair in a dictionary, not to add a new element to a list of dictionaries.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
https://techbeamers.com/python-dictionary/#append-in-a-dictionary

Selected Answer: D
not append(), update() method is correct!

Selected Answer: D
D is the one!

Selected Answer: D
Totally agree with rocky

'dict' object has no attribute 'append' in Python

The answer is correct.
Example:Mapping VSANs to VLANs
The following example shows how to configure the FCoE VLAN and a virtual Fibre Channel interface:
Step 1 Enable the associated VLAN and map the VLAN to a VSAN.
switch(config)# vlan 200
switch(config-vlan)# fcoe vsan 200
switch(config-vlan)# exit
Step 2 Configure the VLAN on a physical Ethernet interface.
switch# configure terminal
switch(config)# interface ethernet 1/4
switch(config-if)# spanning-tree port type edge trunk
switch(config-if)# switchport mode trunk
switch(config-if)# switchport trunk allowed vlan 1,200
switch(config-if)# exit
Step 3 Create a virtual Fibre Channel interface and bind it to a physical Ethernet interface.
switch(config)# interface vfc 4
switch(config-if)# bind interface ethernet 1/4
By default, all virtual Fibre Channel interfaces reside on VSAN 1. If the VLAN to VSAN mapping is to a VSAN
other than VSAN 1, then proceed to Step 4.
Note
Step 4 Associate the virtual Fibre Channel interface to the VSAN.
switch(config)# vsan database
switch(config-vsan)# vsan 200 interface vfc 4
switch(config-vsan)# exit

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
A network engineer must configure FCoE on an interface of a Cisco MDS 9000 Series Switch. It should be used for mapping between VLAN 600 and VLAN 6.
Drag and drop the commands from the bottom into their implementation order in the FCoE configuration. Not all commands are used.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

choices.D: Add VLAN 100 and 200 to the allowed VLANs list on the Ethernet 1/1 interface on N5K-1.
choices.B: Create a static route in VRF WEB for the subnet of Server 2 on N5K-1.
choices.C: Assign VRF WEB membership to interfaces VLAN 150 and 200 on N5K-2
choices.A: Configure access VLAN 100 on interface Ethernet 1/2 on N5K-2.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. The gateway of Server1 is in the VLAN 100 SVI on N5K-1 and the gateway of Server 2 is in the VLAN 200 SVI on N5K-2. Server 1 must connect to Server 2 using unidirectional traffic. Which action accomplishes this requirement?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B

Static route which we see in configuration is not for VRF WEB but for global one. We need to add static routing in VRF WEB
Example
switch# configure terminal
switch(config)# vrf context StaticVrf
switch(config-vrf)# ip route 192.0.2.0/8 192.0.2.10
switch(config-vrf)# copy running-config startup-config

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/nexus9000/sw/6-x/unicast/configuration/guide/l3_cli_nxos/l3_route.html#:~:text=a%20static%20route%3A-,switch%23%20configure%20terminal,switch(config%2Dvrf)%23%20copy%20running%2Dconfig%20startup%2Dconfig,-Verifying%20the%20Static

Selected Answer: B
B is correct!

questions.question_text: An engineer configures a storage environment for a customer with high-security standards. The secure environment is configured in VSAN 50. The customer wants to maintain a configuration and active databases and prevent unauthorized switches from joining the fabric. Additionally, the switches must prevent rogue device from connecting to their ports by automatically learning the WWPNs of the ports connected to them for the first time. Which configuration sets must be used to meet these requirements? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: CE is correct

Selected Answer: CE
The fabric binding feature ensures ISLs are only enabled between specified switches in the fabric
binding configuration. Fabric binding is configured on a per-VSAN basis.
This feature helps prevent unauthorized switches from joining the fabric or disrupting current fabric
operations. 

switch(config)# fabric-binding activate vsan 3 force 
Activates the fabric binding database for the specified VSAN forcefully—even if the configuration is not acceptable.

Selected Answer: CE
i dont know! E is ok C i dont know

choices.D: clear fabric-binding activate vsan 50 fabric-binding activate vsan 50
